That's a great idea! Your parents might have some valuable connections or insights that can help you find a trustworthy clockmaker. They may have had similar experiences with restoring antique items or know someone who has worked with a reliable clockmaker in the past.

It's also possible that your parents might have some knowledge about the clock's history, such as where it was purchased or who originally owned it. This information can be helpful when you're looking for a clockmaker, as they may have specific knowledge or expertise in restoring clocks from a particular era or manufacturer.

Don't hesitate to ask your parents about the clock's history or any potential leads they might have. You can say something like, "Hey, Mom and Dad, I was thinking of getting Grandma's old clock restored. Do you know of any reliable clockmakers in the area who might be able to help me out?"

By involving your parents in the process, you can tap into their knowledge and experience, and they might be able to provide valuable guidance or connections that can help you find the right clockmaker for the job.
